title: 110_s300
content: The Act is titled the "Lower Colorado River Multi-Species Conservation Program Act" and includes definitions for various terms. The Lower Colorado River Multi-Species Conservation Program (LCR MSCP) is a cooperative effort on the Lower Colorado River involving Federal and non-Federal entities in Arizona, California, and Nevada. It was approved by the Secretary of the Interior on April 2, 2005. The Lower Colorado River refers to the Colorado River from Lake Mead to the Southerly International Boundary with Mexico, including its historic floodplain and mainstem reservoirs. Program Documents include the Habitat Conservation Plan, Biological Assessment, Environmental Impact Statement, and Funding and Management. The LCR MSCP involves Federal and non-Federal entities in Arizona, California, and Nevada. The Program was approved by the Secretary of the Interior in 2005. The Program Documents include the Habitat Conservation Plan, Biological Assessment, Environmental Impact Statement, Funding and Management Agreement, Implementing Agreement, and Section 10(a)(1)(B) Permit. The terms "Secretary" and "State" are defined, and the Steering Committee is established pursuant to the Program Documents. The Secretary will manage the LCR MSCP according to Program Documents and enter into agreements with States for water use from the Lower Colorado River. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretary to meet obligations under the Program Documents. The Secretary can invest excess funds in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. All expenditures for the LCR MSCP are non-reimbursable and non-returnable. SEC. 5. APPLICABLE LAW, CONTINUITY OF PROGRAM, ENFORCEABILITY OF PROGRAM DOCUMENTS. SEC. 5 states that nothing in the Act will affect existing rights to Colorado River water. Future acts of Congress cannot modify Program Documents without specific mention. Parties can go to court to enforce agreements related to the LCR MSCP. The United States waives sovereign immunity for actions under this section, allowing it to be named as a defendant in suits related to the LCR MSCP. Suits can be brought in any US district court where a non-Federal party is located. The Act does not affect the enforceability of Program Documents complying with existing law, except for exempting the Steering Committee from the Federal Advisory Committee Act.
